misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Sorting One Parallel Array Updates the Other (Parallel Array Synchronization)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array will automatically keep the names array aligned with the corresponding scores (i.e., that the name attached to the highest score will end up at index n-1 as well).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(z)` only reorders the elements inside `z`. It does not (and cannot) automatically reorder a separate array `y`. Parallel arrays must be kept in sync by swapping both arrays together during sorting, or by sorting indices/objects (e.g., an array/list of `Student{name,score}`) using a comparator. After sorting only `z`, `y[i]` no longer corresponds to `z[i]`.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints the last-entered name (y[n-1]) paired with the highest score (z[n-1]), which often mismatches the real top student.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Incorrect Assumption About Parallel Array Synchronization After Sorting
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when one array is sorted, the elements in parallel arrays automatically reorder themselves to maintain their original pairing. When Arrays.sort(z) is called on the scores array, the student assumes the names array will somehow be reordered in parallel to keep each name matched with its original score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, Arrays.sort() only sorts the specific array passed to it. When sorting one array in a set of parallel arrays, the other arrays do NOT automatically reorder. The correspondence between parallel arrays is broken. After sorting scores in ascending order, the names array remains in its original order, so the pairing between names and scores is lost. For example, if Bob had score 92 (originally at index 1), after sorting the array z, the value 92 is now at index 2, but y[2] still contains 'Charlie', not 'Bob'.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: wrong output - The program will print the name at the last index of the original names array paired with the highest score from the sorted scores array, rather than the correct student who earned the highest score.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting an array (scores) will automatically rearrange a conceptually linked parallel array (names) to preserve the original association between elements.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. The `Arrays.sort()` method only operates on the specific array provided. It has no internal mechanism to synchronize with other arrays that the programmer considers 'parallel'. To maintain the data relationship, either a custom sort must be used to swap elements in both arrays, or the data must be encapsulated in an object-oriented structure.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Arrays Stay Synchronized During Sort
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the `scores` array will also (implicitly) reorder the `names` array in the same way, so that `names[i]` still refers to the student who has `scores[i]` after the sort.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(z)` only rearranges the elements of the single array `z`. It does not know that `y` is a “parallel” array that must be permuted in the same way. After sorting `z`, the mapping between `y[i]` and `z[i]` is broken unless the program explicitly swaps elements in both arrays together (or sorts an array of objects / indices). Therefore, printing `y[n-1]` with `z[n-1]` combines the last original name with the largest score, which can belong to a different student.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (prints incorrect top student name though score may be correct). With sample input, prints `Top student: Charlie (92)` instead of `Bob (92)`.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Arrays Index Pairing Preserved After Single-Array Sort
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when sorting the scores array using Arrays.sort(z), the pairing between names and scores will automatically be maintained. They think that after sorting, y[n-1] will still correspond to the student with the highest score because the arrays will have 'moved together' during the sort.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent data structures. Arrays.sort(z) modifies only the z array in place; it has no effect on the y array. The index pairing that existed before sorting (e.g., y[0] paired with z[0], y[1] paired with z[1], etc.) is completely broken after sorting only one array. To maintain correspondence in parallel arrays, you must explicitly manage the sorting relationship (e.g., swapping elements in both arrays together, using indices, or using objects).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because two arrays are logically linked (parallel arrays), performing an operation like sorting on one array will automatically reorder the elements in the second array to maintain their relationship.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects in memory. The method Arrays.sort(int[]) has no knowledge of other arrays in the program. To maintain parallel array integrity during a sort, the programmer must implement a manual sorting algorithm (like Bubble Sort) that swaps elements in both arrays simultaneously, or use an Object-Oriented approach by creating a Student class.
